snippet.textDisplay: Guys, why modify something that's already perfect ? Fusion is impressive technique but it works rarely and takes a toll on both parts of song. snippet.textDisplay: Great voices, good music, but I give it a thumbs down.  Music, particularly Indian classical, is highly structured with every element, from the ragas to the lyrics, coming together to evoke specific moods.  I associate Aigiri Nandini with a more devotional mood, and the drums/electric guitars/head gyrations with a more raucous and hedonistic mood.  Put the two together, and I am at a loss as to whether I should put my palms together in prayer, or get up and swing my hips.  Purely my limitation - but I have never been able to do both at the same time.  But then, what do I know?
snippet.textOriginal: Great voices, good music, but I give it a thumbs down.  Music, particularly Indian classical, is highly structured with every element, from the ragas to the lyrics, coming together to evoke specific moods.  I associate Aigiri Nandini with a more devotional mood, and the drums/electric guitars/head gyrations with a more raucous and hedonistic mood.  Put the two together, and I am at a loss as to whether I should put my palms together in prayer, or get up and swing my hips.  Purely my limitation - but I have never been able to do both at the same time.  But then, what do I know?

snippet.textDisplay: When the clay idol of Mahishasura Madrini -  Ma Durga is made, the clay is taken from Ganga, but the clay idol of the Goddess is not complete until some clay and dust from the courtesan's house is mixed into the clay for the Goddess. This is a fact. This ritual shows inclusiveness and a representation of the Goddess that is present in all woman from mother to courtesan. This song is like that. The Goddess & the Courtesan are both intertwined within it as one even though their origin seems so disparate to some.
snippet.textOriginal: When the clay idol of Mahishasura Madrini -  Ma Durga is made, the clay is taken from Ganga, but the clay idol of the Goddess is not complete until some clay and dust from the courtesan's house is mixed into the clay for the Goddess. This is a fact. This ritual shows inclusiveness and a representation of the Goddess that is present in all woman from mother to courtesan. This song is like that. The Goddess & the Courtesan are both intertwined within it as one even though their origin seems so disparate to some.

snippet.textDisplay:
God these people who comment dont know what music and shlokas are....

Stop with your stupidity about carnatic music and shloka....

1. ONLY certain scriptures/mantras like in RIG VEDA are supposed to be pronounced in a particular way. Apart from those, a generic shloka (which is also a creation by some person) like Aigiri Nandini has NO RULES thats it has to be sung in a particular way.

2. Carnatic is TYPE of music and there is again NO MENTION that these shlokas have to follow carnatic style. Only dumb people who dont know anything associate these shlokas with carnatic music, and vice versa is also true, that there is no RULE that if the shloka was originally sung in Carnatic it has to maintain that, no there is no such rule.

The fusion of a shloka and some love song might not have made a perfect match, so blame the CHOICE of songs but dont blame them for ruining anything. They are not ruining Carnatic nor are they ruining the Shloka.

*Once again, the choice of mixing these 2 songs was a bad idea BUT it disgraced neither the music nor the shloka.*
snippet.textOriginal:

Only dumb people who dont know anything associate these shlokas with carnatic music, and vice versa is also true, that there is no RULE that if the shloka was originally sung in Carnatic it has to maintain that, no there is no such rule.

The fusion of a shloka and some love song might not have made a perfect match, so blame the CHOICE of songs but dont blame them for ruining anything. They are not ruining Carnatic nor are they ruining the Shloka.

snippet.textDisplay: While I do appreciate the effort put in by the musicians, the whole piece gives me a feeling of having sambar along with cake. Not a good combination. One (ai giri nandini) is supposed to charge you up and another is supposed to mellow you down. But the combination leaves one confused. Also, in my humble opinion, the part of ai giri nandini sounded like Goddess Durga was some kind of terminator like person coming back from the dead or something. Songs that praise God should resonate in the heart and not in the ears.
snippet.textOriginal: While I do appreciate the effort put in by the musicians, the whole piece gives me a feeling of having sambar along with cake. Not a good combination. One (ai giri nandini) is supposed to charge you up and another is supposed to mellow you down. But the combination leaves one confused. Also, in my humble opinion, the part of ai giri nandini sounded like Goddess Durga was some kind of terminator like person coming back from the dead or something. Songs that praise God should resonate in the heart and not in the ears.

snippet.textDisplay: The Mahishasuramardini Stotram (Aigiri Nadini) is neither Carnatic (although it sounds as such) or Hindustani. It is a shloka that is composed in Samskrit.

snippet.textDisplay:
(1)  It indeed is a bad fusion.One can not compare Aigiri Nandini Shlokas with that of Bulle Shah both are miles apart.
(2)Carnatic Music can not be killed with one bad experiment.
(3)Just one Caranatic music composition will surpass all and that is "Endharo Mahanubhavalu".I have yet to find a better alternative. 
 And about North/South part I can only say that it is a sign of not so mature mind as human beings will find some cause to fight,be it color,cast,religion,boundaries,money,gender etc.

snippet.textDisplay: I guess I am among the minority who finds this version offensive. Both from a religious point as well as a bad mix of music. Mahishasura Mardini Stotram is a very powerful slok. While Bulleh Shah in his own right is a class apart in his writing, no where is this Kalaam close to the weight of the slok. There is a trend of musicians picking up sanskrit verses into their songs because they are powerful and drawing to listen to. But they often fail to see that for practicing hindus these verses are holy and they need to be more careful in their treatment of religious verses. At the end of the day the ways of knowledge and art belong to everyone and you are free to mould it as per your view. But in the name of art crossing the line of disrespect is not really the way forward. They killed the song, fine. But calling Durga a "super hero". SERIOUSLY! coz our Goddess are the same as fictional characters like Superman! Don't get smart with me and say Thor is a super hero. Thor is derived from religion that is no longer practiced. But last I checked we still worship Durga even today. She is a god not a super hero.
snippet.textOriginal: I guess I am among the minority who finds this version offensive. Both from a religious point as well as a bad mix of music. Mahishasura Mardini Stotram is a very powerful slok. While Bulleh Shah in his own right is a class apart in his writing, no where is this Kalaam close to the weight of the slok. There is a trend of musicians picking up sanskrit verses into their songs because they are powerful and drawing to listen to. But they often fail to see that for practicing hindus these verses are holy and they need to be more careful in their treatment of religious verses. At the end of the day the ways of knowledge and art belong to everyone and you are free to mould it as per your view. But in the name of art crossing the line of disrespect is not really the way forward. They killed the song, fine. But calling Durga a "super hero". SERIOUSLY! coz our Goddess are the same as fictional characters like Superman! Don't get smart with me and say Thor is a super hero. Thor is derived from religion that is no longer practiced. But last I checked we still worship Durga even today. She is a god not a super hero.

snippet.textDisplay: Aruna Sairam did full justice to this divine prayer to the Mother Goddess, but the rock music and the tere ishq song seemed like rude interruptions.
snippet.textOriginal: Aruna Sairam did full justice to this divine prayer to the Mother Goddess, but the rock music and the tere ishq song seemed like rude interruptions.
